title: Dystopian but no fear
content: This second chapter rewrites more or less the first one, with an apocalyptic fights in the arena. As in the first one, the quality of this saga is in the group of specific symbols and atmospheres that are those of a well defined universe. But this good elements are not at the service of a well done narrative development, that goes without an anxious feeling that instead should be in a dystopian world like this. Characters reactions are not guided by serious fears or sorrows and all the protagonists results static: the interesting dystopian place described is not impregnated by a terrible feeling that instead we have to expect. In this second movie, moreover, the love plot is more presented but, for the same reasons now expressed, it sounds artificial and moralistic, without a real deraglement of the feelings in a horrible situation like the Hunger Games one. Terribly overrated, as the first one.

title: Catching Fire works better the idea of a darker dystopian future, move the franchise ahead and discuss important tpics of our society
content: With the success achieved by the franchise in cinema, it was given carte blanche for this "Hunger Games: Catching Fire" to explore the dystopian universe of Panem in a deeper way and to raise the punishments and challenges imposed on heroes at various levels, in a more cinematic experience. heavy and courageous, precisely because of its politicized nature, something very rare among blockbusters aimed at the youth audience. With the change of direction and an almost unhealthy injection of money (Catching Fire it cost twice as much as the first), two of the original's biggest problems have been completely solved: the camera-in-hand steering and the special effects. Francis Lawrence works action without trying to invent and, in this way, is very efficient in clearly identifying the characters and, when necessary, creating the suspense that the tape requires. The director still does well by joining action scenes, which do not hide the violence of the environment, with others of a certain contemplation. There are several moments when we stop to observe the beauty of the place, either in the forest next to the district where everyone struggles to survive, or in games where the goal is to kill the person next to you. On the side of the effects, we no longer see the terrible "genetically altered dogs" of the climax of the first film and, in their place, we are introduced to very convincing mandrels (a kind of baboon with a colorful snout that actually exists), in addition to shots of the Capital and Arena that actually work.Contrary to many sequels that seem to get worse, "Catching Fire" brings new elements and great developments to the story of Katniss Everdeen. Helped by a book that was certainly designed by Suzanne Collins to have a cinematic structure, and bypassing elements that could take the focus away from the games and psychological conflicts of the characters - like gigantic and empty set pieces or even the tasteless love triangle Katniss-Peeta-Gale (Liam Hemsworth) - we have the great script by Simon Beaufoy (127 Hours) and Michael Arndt (Little Miss Sunshine and Toy Story 3) even though he doesn't have the courage to take any chances. Everything in the book is in the movie. The dialogues are there intact, the sequences in the exact order of the novel, the action scenes, the sacrifices, the secrets, the twists and turns: it is like watching the book in motion. Usually, this is a problem, because the production, excited about the success of the first film and the legion of fans, could have easily set foot in their hands, but in Hunger Games: Catching Fire, the biggest consequence of all this loyalty is a film longer than necessary, plague, incidentally, that fell on the first as well. However, this problem does not detract from the narrative's vigor when it actually begins, although that beginning takes too long to happen and a montage a little less concerned with fan reaction could have prevented it.The second film is much more than "people in an arena trying to kill each other". While the original was basically an American version of the Japanese Battle Royale, the new one invests heavily in political history and in building a climate for the impending revolution. Here, Katniss deals with the consequences of what she was forced to do by the government in the first feature. These consequences are precisely what move the plot, both for the character and for the nation under a totalitarian state controlled by the lush and powerful Capital. The consequences bring responsibilities - and the theme of the dystopian future, in which each citizen indulges in the daily struggle of survival, gains more epic contours while the government encircles freedom of expression with a firm pulse, dispatching scouts to the streets to control demonstrations and keep if in power.Definitely, the biggest success of the film is to accept the dark tone and know how to work it, considering that some adaptations tend to soften the darker content of a work. Following the format of the first film, the first part (more than the first hour of projection) is dedicated almost exclusively to presenting the new situation and developing the characters of this "new universe". Giving space also to present new characters that will be of great importance from that part of the games onwards, showing that The Hunger Games was a child thing. It is also important to highlight how the script treats the protagonist. The events of the first film did not go unnoticed. Katniss from Catching Fire is a traumatized person with everything she has experienced, who finds it difficult to get on with her normal life - which is made worse by the fact that she is forced to go on tour as government propaganda. Even so, the filmmakers were careful not to distort the protagonist: Katniss follows a strong, safe and courageous character, to the point of challenging the president himself. She is that honorable rebel with values that the cinema and the public so much like - no wonder, she is the great force and the main appeal of the entire series.The "tour" and the contrast of the situations experienced by the districts and the Capital are overwhelming for everyone. Gradually, even the alienated Effie (Elizabeth Banks) begins to understand how devastating the status quo of that world is - except for the elite who live in the Capital, far from the suffering of the majority, whose trials sustain their luxuries. The fighting only starts with almost an hour and a half of film already elapsed and the characters themselves recognize that worrying about romance in such a situation would be ridiculous - which adds yet another element of tragedy to the situation of young people, who should not carry such a heavy load on your shoulders. In fact, when we meet Katniss and Peeta, both are suffering from Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome and, through their condition, we come to understand more of Haymitch's suffering (Woody Harrelson). In fact, the very cynical tone with which director Francis Lawrence conducts the narrative is very reminiscent of the mentor's state of mind in the original feature.And anyone who thinks that the Quaternary Massacre is just a repetition of what had already been done is wrong, with the heroes fighting for their lives again. This, in fact, happens. However, the scales involved are bigger (the poisoned smoke, the monkeys and the idea that the arena is a clock that launched the dangers every hour is very good). For the first time, we have the feeling of a broader action unfolding, a real network of intrigues against official leaders. It is precisely at this point that Catching Fire proves to be superior to The Hunger Games. Violence is again present, but in a more subliminal way and inserted in a relevant context. If in the first film we had children and adolescents killing each other indiscriminately, without the necessary reflection for such acts to be perceived and discerned by their main audience - more or less the same age as the characters on the scene - this time there is a conspiracy full of ramifications, with effects and consequences. Everything is part of a plan, even if it is not revealed to the satisfaction. But the important thing is that there is, therefore, something to be told, which finally draws the viewer to the center of the plot. However, "The Hunger Games - Catching Fire" fails to splurge on the edition of the games that are part of the film, propagating that the game will be much more brutal because it has only the winners of the past editions, but what we see are very weak characters to have won a past edition of the game.Once again, the cast stands out and makes everything gain depth and credibility. The film wouldn't work if it weren't for the talent and charisma of Jennifer Lawrence, who has a unique responsibility here. It is the suffering of her Katniss that is put to the public at all times and it is her emotional scars that are exposed in ways that border on sadism, until her final resolution, in which a powerful look from the young actress strikes us in a direct way and the change that took place inside Katniss is palpable. The young actress has a rare ability to say a lot with a simple look and conveys, often without words, the internal conflict of a defiant young woman, who needs to be strong, but at the same time suffers from everything she has gone through and still doesn't really understand the grandeur of the setting in which it was inserted.Catching Fire works better the idea of the dystopian future, planting the seeds for the third part. It is nevertheless interesting to see serious themes being addressed in works of this nature - there is, in addition to the obvious plot about the relationship between the government and the people, a clear criticism of the invasion of privacy and the culture of veneration of celebrities so in vogue nowadays. What is seen, therefore, is not a sequence that is limited to walking in circles, but one that prefers to move forward, expanding the concept initially presented. Francis Lawrence deserves to be praised for the sobriety and seriousness with which he conducts the plot, not letting himself be shaken by the visual exaggerations of the capital, in what could have turned into a meaningless carnival show, worthy of the bread and circus show denounced by the franchise. The subtext of the universe created by Suzanne Collins is even more obvious in the film, but unfortunately it must still pass meters above the heads of a large part of the audience, who are there, ironically, just for the spectacle it represents. Despite dealing with abuse of power, rights and duties of the state, personal sacrifices, and the role of the citizen, comments like "how cool it would be to live in Panem" can be read, proof of the state of critical thinking skills of a fraction of this generation.

title: Surprisingly better than the original.
content: I'm a big fan of the Hunger Games books, and was disappointed by the movie due to the large amount of missed scenes, however this movie surpassed my expectations. There were very few scenes missed from what I remember, and those that were were mainly for continuity from the first film. The acting was just as good, if not better than the first, especially the newer cast members, who I think portrayed their roles really well. The cinematography is also better than the first film in my opinion. I like this film a lot, and certainly was surprised, especially considering the reputation of sequels (even if this was based off an existing book).

title: The filmmakers have done everything they could.
content: "We don't have to destroy her, just her image. Show them that she's one of us now. Let them rally behind that. They're gonna hate her so much they just might kill her for you." Plutarch Heavensbee (Phillip Seymour Hoffman)The Hunger Games: Catching Fire as sequel doesn't as much generate heat as it does satisfaction, the sense that the filmmakers have done just about everything they could to keep our attention, draw our sympathy, and entertain us all the while staying close to its iconic source. Here's a young adult adventure that includes a sensible proletariat heroine, an insensitive ruling class, and romance that reflects the vagaries of humanity's quest for love.Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), on the eve of the 75th Hunger Games, is still torn between respect for her games partner, Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson), and the hunky Gale Hawthorne (Liam Hemsworth). Director Francis Lawrence keeps the focus on the heroine, who, like the rest of us, is flawed, in her case a destructive disdain for corrupt authority figures, embodied in President Snow (Donald Sutherland). Lawrence and d.p. Jo Willems keep us seeing from her point of view, a smart strategy to humanize the inhuman proceedings of child killing child in ultimate survival gaming.Her answer to her difficulties with Capital authority is to tackle a general and marry Peeta, among other impulses. Yet even with this endangerment, the heroine remains a genuine human being, torn between survival and the nagging feeling that she is meant to save her species. That's a big gap, but the film makes it possible to bridge it in the imagination and reality.Beside the mature performance of Lawrence, who makes a teen torn in love both palatable for adults and almost reasonable, Donald Sutherland is powerful as President Snow, white-haired and bearded, a dark force with an ironic snow-white image. His almost tongue-in-cheek authority plays perfectly behind the devastatingly Nazi-like podium and storm-trooper menace to make the evil just a bit lighter than in real life totalitarianism is.In fact, the film is an unusually effective commentary on repressive regimes, currently too many to count on this planet, and the inevitability of the masses rising up. This second installment of The Hunger Game trilogy gets us closer to the rebellion with a heroine both formidable and vulnerable. That's just so much more human than marvelous superheroes who fly above the rest of us."You fought very hard in the Games, Miss Everdeen. But they were games. Would you like to be in a real war? Imagine thousands of your people, dead. Your loved ones, gone." President Snow

title: decent
content: This wasn't too bad a sequel to Hunger Games, as it mostly continues the story of Catniss and her lover from the first movie and the saga they have to continue as being victors from the 75th Hunger Games. This features lots of action, romance, and a decent amount of character development, and some new characters, but it does go on a bit long and tends to drag a bit. If you are a fan of the series, you might not mind those last too bits. Jennifer Lawrence is once again a good choice in the lead role, and the cast does click, as it did in the first movie. If you are a fan of the series and Jennifer Lawrence, you might like this.** 1/2 out of ****

title: a respectable adaptation
content: But it still does not meet the expectations of the book, without a doubt there is nothing better than reading it first and knowing every gap that the movie leaves

title: The shock factor and originality is gone.
content: I guess we are going to see how long we can drag these movies out now. Was not up to par with the original one. The shock factor and originality is gone.

title: My favorite movie out of the series-
content: Absolutely loved this movie. I will admit I was afraid that they would do my favorite book in the series wrong but I watched it anyways with low expectations because I knew that sequels will never be as good as the original, especially when it comes to movies. Oh, I was so wrong! Everyone in this movie gave such amazing performances. I applaud the actors and actresses. Jennifer Lawrence portrays Katniss flawlessly and Josh Hutcherson did splendidly as Peeta. I have never seen actors like these capture the exact essence of their character so perfectly. The casting was so fitting! The animation and CGI is so realistic! They somehow managed to make these Hunger Games so terrifyingly real, especially when it comes to the arena and the fighting sequences. The dialogue is so natural, nothing too odd or forced about it. But my favorite part about this is how they stuck to the book. They executed this movie perfectly and I am still in awe. Nothing in this felt too rushed or too slow: it was paced great and I was never bored. I still rewatch it because it really is an amazing movie. Catching Fire is definitely the best movie out of the series and you will not regret watching it!!

title: Champion of champions.
content: In a way, 'The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)' is the opposite of its predecessor: its first half is strong and its second half is weak. That's right, the game segment of this sequel is arguably its least effective. It falls into the trap of being far too glossy for its own good. While the clean cinematography and refined CGI undeniably impressive, they don't help the film convey the horror of its central situation. In fact, they almost do the opposite, transforming what was once a gritty and uncomfortable scenario into a slice of big-budget blockbuster entertainment. Of course, it isn't just the steady camerawork, effective use of the IMAX format, or reliance on computer graphics that dampens the sequence's effect. Instead, it's the story's reliance on fantastical traps, mostly adult heroes and bloodless combat that reduces the necessary grisliness of its theoretically gory game. Human-on-human combat is present but pushed so far into the background that it's almost irrelevant, and the final act isn't so much a fight for survival as it is an attempt to form a team and stick with it until the end. It doesn't help that our hero is actually a pawn in someone else's game for most of the movie, unbeknownst to her or us. Though this is thematically relevant and comes into play more in the sequels, it leads to an experience that feels as though it relies heavily on last-minute exposition to explain its various twists. It also makes the protagonist feel oddly passive, which is never really a good sign. However, having said all that, the feature is still generally entertaining. It's visually compelling, conceptually interesting and filled with strong performances. As I mentioned earlier, its first half is actually really strong. It immediately feels like an improvement on the non-game elements of the first film, as there's a solid sense of atmosphere from the opening scene. The emotional beats typically work well, actually having some weight behind them because they seem like consequences of prior actions, and the narrative itself is much more interesting than it was in the first hour of the original. There's a sense of political unrest, growing rebellion and underlying threat that wasn't present before, and it makes the affair that much more interesting. Ultimately, though the flick is flawed and doesn't have as strong a finale as I'd like, it's still an enjoyable affair with a few moments of genuine suspense. It's probably a bit better than its predecessor overall.

title: Vive La Revolution!
content:
I like this one just as much as the first. For one thing it has Sam Claflin in it with his chest out, for another, it is the film that connects the first to the last (2), which I realise is an obvious statement, but I mean that in the same way that The Empire Strikes Back (1980) connects Star Wars (1977) and Return Of The Jedi (1983). It's important that the things in this film happen for the series to make sense, where some second films in a trilogy (Quadrilogy) don't always add any value or stand alone entirely.I know my nephews moan that Mockingjay Parts 1&2 are boring and I think that's because those films are very political and don't feature the action of the actual Hunger Games in the ring and I think that this film is great to still show the interesting element of the games with all the politics going on in the background too. In this way it bridges the gap from the first, which was mostly about just the games themselves and the final parts which are much more politic. A nice blend and a slow down as it gets a bit more real, teaching the young adult viewers (and readers) to fight for a worthy cause and not to put up with injustice (but that's the next two, I'm digressing as I always do).You're left with a cliffhanger and a who, what, why feeling as well as a thirst to find out what's next. I know what's coming, because I've seen them before, but I'm still looking forward to the concluding two parts of this four part trilogy, because this one has left me desirous of resolution. I want to know that these characters get to safety and resolve the issues that have arisen.
The direction, acting and production, along with a great story to start with, have made them of interest to me and just like the time when I spent the whole weekend watching Friends and convinced myself that they were all my real friends, I care about what happens to these characters.

title: The games continue.
content: I had few problems with the first movie based on the trilogy of the books authored by Suzanne Collins. The build up was excellent. They really caught the nitty gritty of the reality shows in all its glory of their hypocrisy. And you could sense that there was something 'orwellian' about the whole setting-the bleakness, the play of power and the dearth of freedom. But then the second half happened and all the tension, all that build up was lost to a very timid climax. And all this for what? So that it could earn more bucks by decreasing the viewers' restrictions. I have never understood the criteria by which they rate the movie for the different ages of the audience. No matter how much you tone down the violence the movie, the content of the story, that is brimming with darkness, still works on the mind painting a vivid picture of gore and violence. So if physical display of violence you ban, how would you justify the mental picture of violence that draws itself as soon as the story starts? The rating system is nuts and stupid. Now coming to the movie that I am supposed to be writing about. The second part in the four installments series does everything that its predecessor does, and improves on it. It expands on its 'orwellian settings' giving a detailed bleakness to the state of the affairs and those little flowers of hope that have sprung in that tyrannical state, all thanks to earlier exploits of Jennifer Lawrence's character. The screenplay is coherent and swift and interesting despite the fact that movie is about two and a half hours long. There are few jarring notes here and there in few suspected character developments and unrealistic motives. But that could be forgiven. The ending is abrupt and that is bit of a problem. The greatest accomplishment of the movie is to sway you into that anger, helplessness and hope of the people as it simmers to the boiling point of a rebellion. And yet it makes you question the thin line between the martyrdom and cold blooded murder for the cause. Like every good dystopian world movie, you would be able to identify the roots of the present in that future. I think it did a pretty okay character study with most of the characters. Katniss is torn between safety of her family and the depressing state of the people, between her love for Gale and affection for Peeta and between the demons of the past and the present. Peeta is a disappointment. He seems to be a sort of breed between a puppy and a sitting duck. And that is a pity when so much depth could have been added to him. The Hunger Games: Catching Fire is one of sequels that improves upon its predecessors in every way, but still falls short of greatness. No doubt it is braver than its predecessor, but I wish it could have been bolder.

title: Catching Fire
content: I like it so much. The movie was able to give justice to the book. Every important part of the book was shown in the movie.

title: Impressive Sequel
content: I think this movie offers it all. That may seem strange as I have only rated a 7 but in truth I'm not sure what I would've wanted, it might just be the fact that this movie is just another part of the story that it can't deliver everything. In my opinion it is much better than the first movie as my only real complaint from that one was that the hunger games action didn't really start until the last hour. Although this film had a similar set up, I found the build up to the return to the games was much more interesting and set up a brilliant and thrilling game. title: Love

title: "Our lives aren't just measured in years. They're measured in the lives of people we touch around us."
content: Interestingly, before this rewatch I actually considered this to be one of my least favourite Hunger Games films. Don't get me wrong, in my eyes, each of these installments are 10/10 to me, but my issue with The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013) was that the part where they visit each district did drag for me a fair bit. But that was my only problem with it. And actually, upon this viewing, it didn't drag at all for me, so I've no longer got a problem with that, hence why I now consider this to be a complete masterpiece. What makes this stand out amongst the other Hunger Games movies is the twist, which is cleverly done. You know throughout Act 2 and 3 that something is up, but you just can't quite tell what exactly. And wow, you would never be able to predict the twist, especially a twist of that magnitude. And whenever you rewatch it, it's always interesting to see how it was expertly foreshadowed.And finally, this is the installment where our two protagonists' relationship really blossoms. I truly love the chemistry between the two of them, and it adds a bit of an emotional spark to this franchise which I think might be one of the main reasons why I cherish The Hunger Games so much.

title: The new characters are interesting.
content: I watched the whole series in a row. This movie was the transition. Transition from action movie to war movie. The new characters are interesting. I like the whole series.

I feel bad because my wife had paid for our movie tickets and I did not enjoy the movie at all. I don't see what the big hype and excitement is over these films. I also only read books about actual facts instead of fantasy so reading the books would serve no purpose. If you thought the first movie was mediocre then don't waste your money seeing the 2nd. With the cost of going to the movie theater your better off staying at home and maybe renting or downloading this when it comes out. I'm giving it a 1/10 and would give it a zero but the bar won't go that low.

title: Much Faster, More Visceral, and More Intriguing
content:
The First Hunger Games film did something special. It told a compelling Dystopian type story. This film took the best elements from the first film and REALLY expanded upon them.The first film introduced the idea of the games to us, but this film gave us the argument and philosophy of why the games existed in the first place. This film also did a great job with expanding the world of Panem and it's character storytelling.As far as character moments go, there were alot of great moments from both Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson. Both of them struggling with life after the Games, and how they deal with the
savagery they've witnessed while going through another round of even more savagery in this film. Both are at there peak in this film and continue to shine and grow.Shoutout to Donald Sutherland though. We definitly get to spend more time with him in this film and we really get to see more of what drives him to do what he does, and we get to see some really awesome moments between his character President Snow, and Katniss Everdeen.The imagery and cinematography I believe have really stepped up since the last movie. There were some really beautiful shots. And the music is even more of a standout in this one.Other than that, like I said before, the action is a lot more savage than previous, and definitely more faster paced in my opinion. The Choreography and the action scenes were done really well.I know people say that this film may be the best film in The Hunger Games franchise, but in my opinion, both the 1st and 2nd could be potentially tied for first in my mind. You can't g owrong with either.
